Binomial coefficients

Now that we are familiar with Pascal's triangle, we can proceed to introduce binomial coefficients. There are several different definitions of a binomial coefficient and we will see how we can obtain these definitions via combinatorial arguments. For now we will just say that binomial coefficients are the numbers \({n}\choose{k}\) that make up the entries of Pascal's triangle. These numbers can be calculated by the following formula \[ nCr = {n\choose r} = \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}. \]


Examples

Calculate the following binomial coefficients

  1. \({12}\choose{4}\)
  2. \({n}\choose{0}\)
  3. \({n}\choose{1}\)
  4. \({n}\choose{n}\)

Solutions

  1. We input the required values into the formula above, so we have \[ {12}\choose{4} \] \[ =\frac{12!}{4!8!} = \frac{479001600}{24 \times 40320} = \frac{479001600}{967680} = 495. \]
  2. Here we have \[ {n}\choose{0} \] \[ = \frac{n!}{0!(n-0!)} = \frac{n!}{n!} = 1. \] So any binomial coefficient of the form \({n}\choose{0}\) evaluates to \(1\)
  3. Here we have \[ {n}\choose{1} \] \[ =\frac{n!}{1!(n-1!)} = \frac{n!}{(n-1)!} = \frac{n \times n-1 \times n-2 \times \cdots \times 1}{ n-1 \times n-2 \times \cdots \times 1} = n. \] Thus any binomial coefficient of the form \({n}\choose{1}\) evaluates to the top number \(n\).
  4. Here we have \[ {n}\choose{n} \] \[ =\frac{n!}{n!(n-n)!} = 0! = 1. \] Thus any binomial coefficient of the form \({n}\choose{n}\) evaluates to \(1\) also.
